item.title: Lock please
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

When I read your CSS I found lots of errors, you can’t expect everyone to have the same screenresolution as you.

So use % instead of px.

Like this

<style type='text/css'>
body {color:white}
body {font-size:120%}
body
{
        background-image:url('img/bg.gif');
}
#top {
        
	height: 100px;
        width: 100%;
        text-align: center;
        float: top;
        background-image: url(img/logo.gif);
}
#navigation {
        width: 100%;
        height: 23px;
        text-align: center;
        float: left;
        background-image: url(img/nav.gif);
}
#leftblock {
        margin-top: 3px;
        width: 25%;
        height: 44px;
        text-align: center;
        float: left;
        background-image: url(img/leftblock.gif);
        }
#rightblock {
        margin-top: 3px;
        width: 75%;
        height: 44px;
        text-align: center;
        float: right;
        background-image: url(img/rightblock.gif);
        }
#leftcontent {
        margin-top: 3px;
        width: 25%;
        height: 900px;
        text-align: left;
        float: left;
        background-image: url(img/contentbg.png);
        }
#rightcontent {
        margin-top: 3px;
        width: 75%;
        height: 900px;
        text-align: left;
        float: right;
        background-image: url(img/contentbg.png);
        }
</style>

And don’t use mine, because it is not meant to be a replacement, just a way to show how placement could be done.

Read full topic

item.title: Lock please
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

OK now this is turning into just mean unconstructive bashing. :S

Problems I have with the site:

  • All of the images have “PLEASE DESCRIBE THIS IMAGE” as the alt-text. I have no idea who/what put that there, but it should be a description of the image “Header Image”, “Screenshot of COD 4” etc. Otherwise, text based browsers and even more importantly, apps that people with sight problems use to help with using da internets don’t work.

  • The logo looks, frankly, pretty bad. I symapthise with you on this one, cuz I suck at graphics. If you’re just getting into graphics then I’m sure this is something that will improve, if not just do what I do and find a photoshop bitch you can whip to do this stuff for you.

  • The layout is broken in pretty much every browser. I haven’t looked at the CSS to see why this is, but a quick look at the HTML says that you’re missing end tags a lot, theres no , etc.

  • You’re using XHTML but have no doctype or xml header. Fix dat.

  • It’s probably a good idea to put your stylesheet in a seperate file (or files) and it. This isn’t as important as everything else.

  • Oh, and if you want to make the site look better in the text based browsers FC and I shotted, consider the order of the content in the HTML file. That is, in the body section, lay the content out roughly as “makes sense”, and then use the CSS to position like you are anyway. This is, again, not as important as anything else.

Read full topic

item.title: Lock please
item.dc:creator: @Zero_Freeze ZeroFreeze
item.description:
@Zero_Freeze wrote:

TabbyKiller:

Well it was fine when I first made it but now is just stuffed

No it wasn’t. A site is ‘fine’ if it works in all modern browsers, is functional and is aesthetically pleasing.
Why don’t you rinse your mind from the shit that you have learned from and start learning HTML, CSS and graphics design from the grounds up with some decent resources.

Read full topic

item.title: Lock please
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

Heh, didn’t see your previous work, but after the header it seems to go south kinda, the background is horrible, a screenshot for background makes a site way too crowded in 99.99999% of all cases, also the header is too big, make it small and centered, also make it blend in with a background color… Use another font for the site’s content and those view buttons also don’t work, white text on a yellow button = bad idea… Try making a centered area under a header for the content with a links bar under the header like now, that’ll work a lot better. And again, make sure you center it, people with big monitors have lots of space to put stuff, if the whole site is aligned to the right or left side, or in this case, both sides, it won’t look too good… Hope that helps, good luck

Read full topic

item.title: Lock please
item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller
item.description:
@TabbyKiller wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:17, topic:313854”]When making websites you should alway test them in at least 2 browsers, unless you want them to fail. I usually test in firefox and konqueror (same engine as chrome/safari) and usually in an IE6 I have installed under linux. Usually if you follow conventions though most things work.

You can fix your errors (and probably fix in most browsers) by referring to here:
http://validator.w3.org/check?uri=http%3A%2F%2Fmodernwarfare.ulmb.com%2Findex.php&charset=(detect+automatically)&doctype=Inline&group=0[/quote]
Hey thanks for that, ill be sure to fix it up when i get on my pc

Read full topic

item.title: Lock please
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

When making websites you should alway test them in at least 2 browsers, unless you want them to fail. I usually test in firefox and konqueror (same engine as chrome/safari) and usually in an IE6 I have installed under linux. Usually if you follow conventions though most things work.

You can fix your errors (and probably fix in most browsers) by referring to here:
http://validator.w3.org/check?uri=http%3A%2F%2Fmodernwarfare.ulmb.com%2Findex.php&charset=(detect+automatically)&doctype=Inline&group=0

Read full topic
